rLOGTx-y5.memHandModelNotes:
Brackish/Salt water type was selected for this species, but since water is selected as a map unit, this should serve to limit this species' model to Brackish/Salt water habitats.  I therefore un-selected water type from the drop-down menu above. MJR 29aug07.

Added FW and SW 120m and 9999 (unlimited) FROM and INTO buffers respectively. MJR 30 January 2008.

habitat_description:
The loggerhead sea turtle is distributed from the warmer portions of the Atlantic, Pacific, and Indian oceans. Also found in the Caribbean and Mediterranean seas (Bolten et al. 1992). This species is mostly absent from mainland shores. It is important to mention the major nesting congregations take place in the temperate and subtropical areas of southeastern U. S., Mexico, Australia, Oman, South Africa, the Mediterranean, and Japan (Dodd 1992). The largest nesting aggregation (30000 females per year) takes place on Masirah Island, Oman. In the United States, the nesting range is found along the Atlantic coast from North Carolina to southern Florida (Dodd 1988; Shoop 1985). The primary nesting areas occur in Brevard, St. Lucie, Martin, Palm Beach, Broward, and Indian River counties, Florida (6000-15000 females per year) (Natureserve.org).

The nesting areas are open sandy beaches above high-tide mark, seaward of well developed sand dunes. Also, high energy beaches on barrier strands adjacent to continental land masses. Preferred beaches are often characterized by having gradual slopes (Natureserve.org). In Florida, nesting occurs in urban beaches where tall buildings and trees obscure the city lights and thus posing as adequate nesting sites (Salmon et al. 1995). Smaller nesting sites are found in Virginia and New Jersey, and also on barrier islands along the Texas coast (Shopp and Kenney 1992). 

Habitat includes bays, lagoons, shorelines, river mouth, and tidal flats. Also found in sand dunes (Natureserve.org). Chesapeake Bay is an important area of suitable habitat during the summer. It also occurs in the northeastern coast of the United States between Long Island and Cape Hatteras (Shopp and Kenney 1992). From shores, this species roams more than 500 miles away, mostly over continental shelf, estuaries, creeks, lagoons, mouths of rivers, and bays. These areas ore described as warm temperate and subtropical zones (Coles and Musick 2000). Habitats occupied by adults include turbid bays and clear waters of reefs, while juveniles are primarily found near shorelines and in estuarine situations.
